contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Cochoas | image = Cochoa viridis 2.jpg | image_caption = Green Cochoa ''(Cochoa viridis)'' | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Aves]] | ordo = [[Passeriformes]] | familia = [[Turdidae]] | genus = '''''Cochoa''''' | genus_authority = [[Brian Houghton Hodgson|Hodgson]], 1836 | subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] | subdivision = ''[[Purple Cochoa|Cochoa purpurea]]''<br /> ''[[Green Cochoa|Cochoa viridis]]''<br /> ''[[Sumatran Cochoa|Cochoa beccarii]]''<br /> ''[[Javan Cochoa|Cochoa azurea]]'' }} The '''cochoas''' (from ''cocho'', [[Nepali language|Nepali]] for ''[[Cochoa purpurea]]'')<ref>{{Cite book| last = Jobling| first = James A.| title = A Dictionary of Scientific Bird Names| publisher = Oxford University Press| location = | year = 1991| page = 57| isbn = 0-19-854634-3 }}</ref> are medium-sized frugivorous, insectivorous and molluscivorous [[bird]]s in the genus ''Cochoa''. Their bright contrasting plumage patterns, sexual dimorphism and feeding habits made their systematic position difficult to ascertain in early times, [[Richard Bowdler Sharpe]] placed them with the [[Prionopidae]] in 1879 while many considered them as some kind of aberrant thrush.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ripley SD|year=1952|title= The thrushes|journal= Postilla| volume= 13|pages= 1–48|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/postilla150peab#page/n116/mode/1up}}</ref> Recent molecular studies have suggested that there is support for their inclusion in the [[thrush (bird)|thrush]] family Turdidae, while some suggest a relationship closer to the [[Old World flycatcher]] family Muscicapidae.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S1055-7903(03)00191-X|author=Voelker, G., Spellman, G.M.|year=2004|title=Nuclear and mitochondrial evidence of polyphyly in the avian superfamily Musicapoidea| journal=Mol. Phylogenet. Evol. |volume=30|issue=2|pages= 386–394|pmid=14715230}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title= A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the ‘‘true thrushes’’ (Aves: Turdinae)| author=Klicka, J; G Voelker; & Garth M. Spellman|journal= Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume= 34|issue= 3 |year=2005|pages=486–500|pmid= 15683924 | doi= 10.1016/j.ympev.2004.10.001 | url= http://faculty.unlv.edu/jrodriguez/Klicka2005.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Multi-locus phylogenetic analysis of Old World chats and flycatchers reveals extensive paraphyly at family, subfamily and genus level (Aves: Muscicapidae)|author=Sangster, G;Per Alström ;Emma Forsmark & Urban Olsson| journal=Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume=57|issue=1 |year=2010|pages= 380–392|pmid=20656044 |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2010.07.008|url=http://www.nrm.se/download/18.3ebfe5cf12a9d3ebacb80002787/Sangster+et+al+2010+Muscicapidae+MPE.pdf}}</ref> These are southeast [[Asia]]n forest-dwelling species, often found near water.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}<!-- the near water bit needs citation --> * [[Purple Cochoa]], ''Cochoa purpurea'' * [[Green Cochoa]], ''Cochoa viridis'' * [[Sumatran Cochoa]], ''Cochoa beccarii'' * [[Javan Cochoa]], ''Cochoa azurea'' ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Cochoa|*]] [[Category:Bird genera]]
